content:
1. CE Marking This equipment conforms to the EU machinery Directive 2006/42/EC (description A1 below) and EMC

Directive 2014/30/EU (description A2 below).

However, this equipment does not bear CE marking if a custom order item was installed.

A1.

Cautions regarding the official language of EU countries and the language used in operation manuals, CE declarations, operation screen characters, and warning labels when this equipment is installed in an EU country.

• All materials except warning labels are written in English only.

NOTE

Warning labels only have pictograms or else include warning messages in English, Chinese, Korean and Japanese languages.

A2.

EMC description

• Electromagnetic immunity (Immunity)

Complies with test standards as specified by EN 61000-6-2.

• Electromagnetic emissions (Emission)

Complies with test standards for ISM category: Group 1, Class A, as specified by EN 55011.

NOTE

Complies with test standards for ISM category: Group 1, Class A, as specified by EN 55011.

NOTE

Class A equipment is intended for use in industrial environments. If used in other environments, ensuring electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) might be difficult. Refer to EN 55011 standards for detailed information.

2 Warning Labels 

warning labels are attached to the machine body and peripheral equipment to use YAMAHA machines

safely and correctly. Check that the information on each warning label is clearly legible and comply with

the instructions.

2.1 Warning Label Format and Mark Descriptio

2.1.1 Warning Label Format

A warning label indicates the degree of hazard by means of a signal word and the color of the signal word panel as shown below. A mark and a pictogram are also used to emphasize the message.

Labels attached to the outside of machines are basically in four languages (English, Japanese, Chinese,

and Korean) while labels attached to the inside of the machines are only a pictogram.

Warning label format

Warning message and mark (pictogram) example

Path Image Warning label format : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Warning_Labels/Safety_Instructions_2_2.1_2.1.1_Warning_label_format.png

2.1.2 Mark Description

The mark of warning label includes following three types. Each mark has its own meaning and is typically used with a pictogram to emphasize the message.

Mark and pictogram

Marks and examples used with pictogram

Path Image Warning mark : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Warning_Labels/Safety_Instructions_2_2.1_2.1.2_Warning_mark.png

Path Image Prohibition mark :

Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Warning_Labels/Safety_Instructions_2_2.1_2.1.2_Prohibitio_mark.png

Path Image Instruction mark : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Warning_Labels/Safety_Instructions_2_2.1_2.1.2_Instruction_mark.png

|   | Warning | Prohibition | Instruction |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Definition | Indicates a hazard, how to  avoid the hazard, and potential  consequences of ignoring the  warning. | Indicates a prohibited action  to avoid the potential hazard. | Indicated an action that must  be taken to avoid the potential  hazard. |
| Shape/Color | Yellow triangle with black  border. Pictogram is black on  yellow. | Red circle with slash.   Pictogram is black and located  behind slash. | Blue circle. Pictogram is white  on blue. |
| Message   example | Risk of electrical shock | Do not modify or disassemble  safety cover switch. | Read the manual to understand  procedure before starting  operation. |

3 Label Positions

The following warning/caution labels are attached to YAMAHA products to ensure safe and correct use.

Check that the information on each label is clearly legible and comply with the instructions.

For safety precautions other than those on the labels shown in this section, see the instructions in

“4. Safety”.

NOTE

• Labels are basically attached to the positions as below, although they may differ slightly      depending on specifications, etc.

• See “1.2 Power Connection Terminals” in Appendix of the Maintenance manual for detailed information on connecting

power to this equipment.

4 Safety

To ensure that the machine you purchased is used safely and correctly, always comply with the instructions and rules in this manual regarding safety. However this manual cannot cover all items regarding safety in detail. So it is extremely important that the operator or person handling the machine make correct decisions regarding safety.

4.1 To Ensure Safety

To maintain the safety of the operator or person working with this machine, it is essential that it (including

external parts feeders) be installed correctly in compliance with the safety standards and conditions of

that country.

Complying with the safety regulations and laws of that country is the responsibility of the customer who

purchased this machine. The supervisor of this machine must take responsibility to ensure all measures

have been taken for machine safety.

4.1.1 Defining Safety

1. Safety has priority over all other operations.

2. Safety is more important than any other task.

3. Safety is the foundation for work efficiency.

4. Safety begins with maintaining (keeping it neat and orderly) the work environment.

4.1.2 Causes of Injuries and Accidents

Most accidents are not something that occurs but something that are caused.

Therefore, it is important to make an effort NOT to cause accidents.

Hazardous actions

• Ignoring causes of accidents

• Working or operating equipment in cramped locations

• Working in locations or positions where safety cannot be ensured

• Unsafe machine operation and using equipment whose safety cannot be ensured

• Working or operating equipment at speeds where safety cannot be ensured

• Working or operating machines with safety equipment removed

• Performing work or tasks on top of a machine currently in operation

• Playing around or goofing off during work

• Performing maintenance or inspections without wearing safety gear

4.2 Using Safety Gear

Always wear safety gear when operating or servicing equipment.

Helmet: 		   Use during maintenance work.

Safety glasses or goggles: Use around light harmful to eyes and when applying lubricant and when

handling organic solvents.

Respiratory gear:	   Use when handling organic solvents.

Safety gloves: 		   Use when applying lubricant and when handling organic solvents.

4.3.1 Defining Operator and Service Representative

CAUTION

Only the operator and service representative having sufficient knowledge of this machine should handle this machine.

Operator

The operator is someone who has been trained by us in machine operation, has a thorough knowledge

of the machine operation manual and demonstrates adequate knowledge of machine operation and

safety. Main tasks of the operator include pre-operation checks, operation, and making setups

(changeovers). The machine is only used in normal operating mode.

Service representative

The service representatives are those trained by us in machine maintenance as well as safety

instruction and demonstrate a thorough knowledge of safe handling of the machine according to the

type and location of machine operation. They must also understand hazardous sections of the machine

and residual risks.

Main tasks of the service representative include machine maintenance, repair, adjustment and

Main tasks of the service representative include machine maintenance, repair, adjustment and

management of the system. The service representative may make changes to the machine settings and

operation in factory adjustment mode.

4.3.2 Restricting machine Operation with Passwords

machine operating levels usable by the operator and service representative (mentioned above) must be

restricted by password. This prevents the operator and service representative from using the machine at a higher level than allowed.

4.3.3 Lock Out Main Switch and Air Supply/Exhaust Switch

When the maintenance work is performed with the power supply and the air supply off, make sure to lock the main switch and the air supply/exhaust switch with a padlock as shown below before the work. This is to prevent a bystander from accidentally turning on the power and the air supply during the maintenance work. Also, make sure to lock the main switch and the air supply/exhaust switch with a padlock when the machine is left unused for a long period of time. Manage the key of the padlock according to the customer's rules.

Lock out the main switch and the air supply/exhaust switch

content:
4.4 Cautions During machine Operation

• Always make pre-operation checks before powering on the machine.

• Do not use an air blow tool when cleaning the machine.

(airborne dust will badly affect machine operation.)

• stop all machine operation before cleaning around the machine.

• Do not turn off the air during operation.

• Always make periodic inspections to prevent unexpected machine breakdowns.

• Allow only properly trained, experienced workers to perform repair and adjustment.

4.5 Cautions During Power Outage

If a power outage (blackout) occurs during automatic machine operation, always power off the machine to prevent faulty operation and equipment damage after power has been restored. Remove items such as boards that remain inside the machine.

4.6 Cautions Regarding Ferromagnetic Fields

Some machines contain parts generating strong magnetic fields which may cause death, bodily injury, or device malfunction. Always comply with the following instructions.

• Persons wearing electronic medical devices such as cardiac pacemakers and/or hearing aids must not put any of their body parts into the machine.

• Persons wearing ID cards, purses, and/or wristwatches must keep away from the linear motor.

• Do not attempt to disassemble the linear motor (including surrounding covers).

• Do not bring tools close to the linear motor.

• Do not bring tools close to the magnetic scale.

• Do not put magnetic materials or objects close to the linear motor.

• Do not touch a portion close to the linear motor during operation or immediately after the operation has been finished since such part is hot.

CAUTION

CAUTION

When disposing of a part generating strong magnetic fields such as a linear motor, dispose of it in compliance with the laws and regulations of the country where the machine is used. Contact your distributor for disposal of the parts.

4.7 Handling Internal Tape Cutter

The internal tape cutter could cause severe injury if misused. Adhere strictly the following precautions.

• Never supply electrical power and air to the machine while the covers of tape cutter are removed.

• Never put your hands or fingers into the tape emitting duct of the tape cutter.

• Never touch the tape cutter blade.

• tape cutter maintenance tasks must be performed by your service representative.

NOTE

YAMAHA recommends to inspect a tape cutter (and to lubricate with disassembly if needed) once a year, although this may vary depending on the machine condition or machine operating environment. YAMAHA also recommends to replace tape cutter blade once every three years. Contact your distributor for more details.

4.8 Keeping Hands Away from Moving Parts

During use of this machine, the customer’s equipment and operating conditions might allow the operator’s hands to come into contact with moving parts. Use the following safety measure options to avoid possible danger where openings or gaps are found on the machine.

Dummy feeder

Use dummy feeders as safety measures to fill a gap between tape feeders. Install dummy feeders on

the feeder plate the same way as normal feeders in order to prevent hands from entering.

Prevention of hand and object entry

Dummy feeder

Path Image Prevention of hand and object entry Dummy feeder : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Safety/Safety_Instructions_4_4.8_Dummy_feeder.png

CAUTION

CAUTION

To install or remove a dummy feeder, be sure to first press emergency stop button and then open cover. The machine has structure that does not allow installing or removing dummy feeder when machine is in operation. However, inserting dummy feeder inside cover during operation may cause serious accidents, so be careful not to attempt it.

One-stop cover (for machines with feeder exchange carriages)

When a feeder exchange carriage is not in use on a carriage-type machine, install a one-stop cover in

the position where the feeder exchange carriage is to be installed to prevent hand entry.

Prevention of hand entry

One-stop cover

Path Image One-stop cover : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Label_Positions/Safety_Instructions_4_4.8_Onestop_cover.png

Path Image One-stop cover Type : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Label_Positions/Safety_Instructions_4_4.8_Onestop_cover_type.png

CAUTION

CAUTION

To remove the one-stop cover with the lower opening cover, be sure to remove it while holding its opening with hand and supporting it.

NOTE

One-stop covers cannot be installed or removed during operation. The machine must be in a stopped state because the feeder exchange carriage setting part needs to be moved up and down when installing or removing the feeder exchange carriage.

Precautions for using one-stop cover (for machines with feeder exchange carriages)

Using different one-stop covers depending on the safety cover specification will increase safety.

Prevention of hand entry

Precautions for using one-stop cover

Path Image Precautions for using one-stop cover : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Safety/Safety_Instructions_4_4.8_Onestop_cover_Precautions.png

Muzzle plate

Use these plates as a safety measure for the board conveyor entrance and exit openings.

Use these plates as a safety measure for the board conveyor entrance and exit openings.

Each plate is movable, so adjust the mounting position to match the boards to be produced.

Muzzle plate

Path Image Muzzle plate : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Safety/Safety_Instructions_4_4.8_Muzzle_plate.png

| Supported machine | Upper clearance | Lower clearance | Remarks |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| YRM20 | Dual-stage type | 0 to 40 mm | 0 to 40 mm | From board conveyor surface |
| YRM20 | Single-lane type | 0 to 40 mm | 0 to 40 mm | From board conveyor surface |
| YRM20DL | 0 to 40 mm | 0 to 50 mm | From board conveyor surface |

NOTE

The values above show the maximum adjustable range of the muzzle plate.

See the product specification of each machine for the component mountable height and the restrictions of the substrate.

CAUTION

When installing a unit such as a loader or an unloader on the upstream or the downstream side of the machine, set the muzzle plates to the opening of the board conveyor entrance or the board conveyor exit to make the opening small.

4.9 Handling Solvents (Including Solder, Adhesive, and Flux)

Cleaning organic solvents, such as isopropyl alcohol (IPA) and ethanol are used for the maintenance of this machine (including optional units). Additionally, the solder paste printers, dispensers, and some hybrid placers and flip chip bonders use solder, flux, or bond, etc. during normal production. As many of these materials include organic solvents, great care should be taken when handling them.

Cautions on handling solvents

1. Harmful to human body

Organic solvents constantly vaporize and contaminate the surrounding atmosphere. Inhaling or

coming in contact with organic solvent vapor may cause serious damage to human health.

2. Flammability

Organic solvents are highly flammable substances and can easily catch fire if handled improperly.

3. Adverse effects on machines

Some kind of solvent may deteriorate parts used in the machine, electric cable sheathes, and other

resin parts.

To prevent accidents caused by solvents

resin parts.

To prevent accidents caused by solvents

1. Be careful not to inhale toxic vapors of solvents for extended periods.

2. Do not use solvents near fire or flame. Keep solvents away from flame or fire.

3. Use only the specified solvent in the correct manner. Do not reuse any solvent repeatedly, and do not

mix with other solvents or chemicals.

4. Check the contents of the safety data sheet (SDS), thoroughly notify work personnel of toxicities of

included chemical materials and measures to be taken in case of an accident, and take necessary

countermeasures.

5. Use appropriate safety gear (safety goggles, protective gloves, and respiratory protective devices)

corresponding to the solvent or material types.

6. See the safety data sheet for how to dispose the solvents and the cloths used for wiping off the

solvents.

CAUTION

solvents.

CAUTION

If no safety data sheets are supplied with solvents or materials you have purchased, be sure to acquire the safety data sheets from the suppliers.

4.10 Handling Laser

This machine (including optional units) has portions using the laser, such as a sensor and barcode reader. This device is a Class 1 laser product. (IEC60825-1: 2014, FDA (CDRH) Part 1040.10)

Path Image Handling Laser : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Safety/Safety_Instructions_4_4.10_laser.png

CAUTION

Use of controls or adjustments or performance of procedures other than those specified herein may result in hazardous radiation exposure.

Knowledge and information about laser

1. Harmful to human body

Never look at the laser directly even when it is weak. In particular, if the laser is irradiated to an eye

for a long time, this may cause serious injury.

2. Reflection of laser

The laser is reflected by a glass or metal surface. Pay special attention to the reflected laser light

during maintenance work.

To prevent accidents caused by laser

1. Do not align your eye with the laser height so that you do not look at the laser directly.

1. Do not align your eye with the laser height so that you do not look at the laser directly.

2. Shield the laser during work, when necessary.

4.11 Handling Grease and Oil

Grease or oil is applied to the operating axes of this machine. When performing the lubrication work, strictly observe the cautions shown below.

Cautions on handling grease and oil

1. If grease or oil enters your eye or sticks to your skin, this may cause inflammation. Be sure to wear

safety goggles and protective gloves during work. Additionally, if you swallow grease or oil by

mistake, this may cause vomiting or diarrhea.

2. If grease other than specified is used, this may cause damage to the machine.

3. If grease with different characteristics is mixed with proper grease, this may cause the machine performance to lower.

4. Be sure to cap tightly after use to prevent entry of dust or water content. When storing the grease or oil, avoid the direct sunlight, keep it away from a fire, and store it in a dark place.

NOTE

When the safety data sheet (SDS) about the grease or oil that is used for the maintenance wok is needed, contact your distributor.

4.12 Handling Batteries

Batteries are used for some motors of this machine and the optional BACKUP UNIT (Uninterruptible Power Supply unit).

Cautions on handling batteries

1. Do not disassemble the battery or touch its inside. Otherwise, electrical shock may result.

2. Do not over-heat or apply a strong impact to the battery. Otherwise, fluid leakage, explosion, or heat generation, etc. may result. Never use the battery, to which a strong impact has been applied, such as dropping to the floor since its battery fluid may leak.

3. Only engineers who have the experience and knowledge about electrical work are allowed to replace the battery.

4. The battery may discharge naturally. When purchasing a spare battery, do not store it for a long period and prepare it one to two months before the scheduled replacement work. Additionally, when storing the battery, avoid a place where the temperature increases and be sure to store it at room temperature.

NOTE

NOTE

When the safety data sheet (SDS) about the battery is needed, contact your distributor.

CAUTION

See the user's manual prepared by the battery manufacturer that is supplied with the BACKUP UNIT for details about how to handle BACKUP UNIT.

CAUTION

Dispose of a battery in compliance with the laws and regulations of the country where the machine is used. Contact your distributor for any questions about disposal of the battery.

4.13 Handling Heavy Objects

This machine (including optional units) may require the operator to handle heavy objects during work. (For example, magazine or cassette replacement) If you hold up a heavy object in an unnatural posture, this may cause damage to your back. Additionally, if you fall a heavy object to your feet, this may cause serious personal injury. Or, falling a heavy object may cause damage to the magazines or internal tray components.

Cautions on handling heavy objects

1. Be careful not to take an unnatural posture during work. In particular, be aware that you may take an

unnatural posture easily when holding up a heavy object from a low place. It is recommended to hold

up a heavy object by bending and stretching your knee instead of bending your waist or prepare a

cart with an appropriate height when necessary.

2. When handles are provided, such as magazine or cassette, hold the handle securely and perform the

work.

work.

3. To prevent personal injury caused by heavy object dropping, be sure to wear safety shoes.

CAUTION

When heavy object handling standards are defined at the customer's factory, be sure to follow the standards during work.

The contents that must be followed to prevent users and third parties from injury and damage to a

machine are explained as “Warning” and “Caution” in this manual. The contents that are required and

helpful information when operating a machine are explained as “Note” and “Tip”.

1 About This Manual

The instruction manual of this machine is written for those who operate this machine. Please read this

manual carefully for correct operations and pay special attention to safety precautions.

after reading through this manual, please use this manual as an occasional reference and keep it within

reach.

Contents description

The maintenance parts (parts numbers) given in this manual are the original parts numbers which were

assigned to the parts when this manual was issued. Because these parts numbers may be changed

without prior notice, be sure to verify the latest parts numbers by contacting your distributor before

ordering parts.

Also, this manual is not a periodical publication. Browse the YAMAHA Surface Mounter Support &

Service website when the latest information is required.

NOTE

See “2. User Support” in Appendix for the YAMAHA Surface Mounter Support & Service website.

2 Contents of Each Chapter

This manual is comprised of the following chapters.

Chapter 1 Maintenance

Describes operating conditions and environments necessary to maintain the machine performance, and

the importance of the daily check work and cleaning work. Setups to make before starting maintenance

work, consumable parts and maintenance tools as well as the necessary tools are also described.

Chapter 2 Daily Maintenance Items

Making checks and cleaning the machine are essential daily maintenance tasks for maintaining

equipment performance. Performing these tasks prevents unforeseen trouble and allows using the

machine in an optimum state.

Chapter 3 Periodic Maintenance Items

Describes maintenance tasks that should be performed periodically to maintain equipment

performance.

Each maintenance items are set recommended maintenance intervals, such as “weekly”, “monthly”,

“3-month”, “6-month”, or “1-year”, other than “daily”. Describes details of maintenance items which are

checking, cleaning, methods of lubrication to each axes and parts replacement.

See “Chapter 5 How to replace consumable parts” for the replacement procedure of consumable parts

.

Chapter 4 Lubricating Points

Provides information regarding the lubrication points, lubrication tools, and the lubrication schedule for

the axes described in “Chapter 3 Periodic maintenance items”.

Chapter 5 How to Replace Consumable Parts

Provides information regarding the consumable parts, such as nozzle or leaf spring, and other

replacement parts such as bulbs.

Appendix

Provides information regarding the specification, such as supply air pressure, power supply connection

unit, and input/output signals.

Also provides information of “User support”.

WARNING

THE “SAFETY INSTRUCTIONS” IN THIS DOCUMENT SHOULD BE READ BEFORE THE MAINTENANCE OPERATION.

tape cutter maintenance

The following maintenance cycles are recommended for tape cutter.

• Inspection of tape cutter (disassembly and lubrication as necessary): Every one year

• Replacement of tape cutter damper: Every three years for machines with HM head units,

every one year for machines with RM head unit

• Replacement of tape cutter blades: Every three years

The above maintenance works must be performed by service representative, since failure of these

works could result in serious injury. Contact your distributer for details.

Vacuum pump maintenance

The vacuum pump for RM head unit is not maintainable, it is a consumable item.

For details on how to replace it, see “7.1.2 Replacing Vacuum Pump” in Chapter 3.

1 Maintaining machine Performance

The most important condition essential for maintaining the performance of the machine you purchased is

using it under good environmental conditions. Performing daily maintenance and periodic inspections is

also absolutely essential.

1.2 Importance of Periodic Inspections and Cleaning

Periodic inspections and cleaning are extremely important maintenance tasks. Failure to perform

inspections and cleaning will prevent the machine from delivering full performance and may lead to

component mounting problems or equipment breakdowns.

Examples of machine malfunction:

• Dirty nozzle may cause the miss-recognition of nozzle itself and raise mounting failure.

• Dirty air path may cause frequent pick-up/mounting errors.

• Inadequate inspection of feeder or feeder plate may cause frequent pick-up errors.

• Dirty optical system (camera, lighting, etc.) may cause recognition errors.

• Poor greasing of axes may cause abnormal noises.

• Inadequate inspection of valve etc may cause failure in clamping and transferring a board.

As these examples show, failure to make periodic inspection and cleaning may lead to equipment

problems. It is strongly recommended to perform periodic inspections and cleaning to ensure the machine is used under optimal conditions.

1.3 Importance of Appropriate Humidity Management

The inappropriate humidity management of the machine installed floor, it triggers dew drops and may

damage the control circuit inside of machine.

Perform the following items to secure machine endurance.

Check temperature and humidity of your site before turning on machines.

• Actuate the air conditioner, humidifier, or dehumidifier to adjust the temperature and humidity

matched to the environmental condition described in “1.1 Essential Conditions and Working

Environment” in this chapter, confirm the temperature and humidity of your site settle, and then turn

on machines.

Use humidifier adequately.

• Use the water without much impurity for humidifier.

• The spray type humidifier should be installed at high place enough from machines. Adjust the amount

of mist to prevent the dew drops on machine surface.

• Adjust the humidifier operation as necessary. Especially the using of humidifier in humid period, the

humidity may excess 80%.

TIP

humidity may excess 80%.

TIP

The water without much impurity refers to that is filtered by the dedicated equipment.

The impurity amount of filtered water can be perceived by the electrical conductivity of water (S/cm);

• General tap water in Japan: 100 to 400 μS/cm

• Filtered tap water: Approximately 1 to 2 μS/cm

(As the purity of water varies depending on the performance of filtering equipment, consult to the equipment manufacturer for details.)

CAUTION

For your humidifier, DO NOT use tap water or well water. Those water include small amount of elements as such Natrium or Chlorine, may cause a decline of insulation, and it may damage the circuit inside of machine.

NOTE

The nozzles named “80XX” (example: 8004H, 8006H) are called as the “Standard nozzle (wide range nozzle)” and those of “81XX” (example: 8101A, 8102A) as the “Neighboring nozzle”. The “Standard nozzle” can adopt wide range of component size to be picked up, in otherwise the “Neighboring nozzle” can be set the neighboring intervals for each nozzles.

For HM head units, they are shipped with the nozzle group setting on [machine Setting] > [machine Information] > [machine Variation Setting] screen as “80XH (standard type)” or “81XH (neighboring type)”. For RM head units, the setting is only “81XH (neighboring type)”.

Before Maintenance Work

In most cases, maintenance should be performed after powering off the machine.

However, some maintenance tasks are performed under emergency stop conditions with the power turned

on. In such cases, ensure adequate safety and press the emergency stop before beginning the

maintenance.

Power on the machine during maintenance where any servo-axis must be operated or machine operation

checked. In this case, also ensure adequate safety before beginning the maintenance.

When operating the machine, make sure the following conditions are met.

Operating condition

1. Supply air pressure is kept at correct pressure.

2. All safety covers are closed.

3. All feeder exchange carriages are clamped.

4. nozzles and other units are attached in place.

NOTE

The description “Cancel the emergency stop” is in the procedures of this manual. It means “rotating the emergency stop button to release and pressing the [READY] button to turn the servo on”.

When performing inspection and maintenance work, strictly observe the cautions

shown below.

• Periodic inspections and maintenance work must be performed by or under the control of a person

who has received training from YAMAHA or an authorized distributor.

• Always power off the machine before inspecting mechanical parts.

However, if inspection is necessary while mounter power is on, the human body should never be in

the moving range of the axes.

• Do not allow foreign objects to enter during inspection or maintenance.

• Use only the greases specified by YAMAHA.

• When the machine needs to be replaced the parts, use parts approved by YAMAHA.

• Do not modify the machine body or parts used. Any modifications by the customer may not only

make it impossible to meet specifications, but also make it impossible to maintain safety.

When performing replacement of consumable parts, strictly observe the precautions

shown below.

When performing replacement of consumable parts, strictly observe the precautions

shown below.

• Replacement of consumable parts must be performed by or under the control of a person who has

received training from YAMAHA or an authorized distributor.

• When performing the replacement of consumable parts, always press the emergency stop button.

• Do not allow foreign objects to enter during the parts replacement.

• Use only the replaceable parts specified by YAMAHA.

• Do not modify the machine or the parts. Any modifications made by the customer may deviate from

the normal specifications and may interfere with safety assurance.

Sometimes the upper cover will be detached during machine set-up or maintenance work.

1 Checking Nozzle Conditions

If solder adheres onto a nozzle tip or a nozzle hole becomes clogged with solder, a component pick-up

error or recognition error may occur. Moreover, poor spring action of nozzles may cause pick-up errors. to To prevent these errors, inspect each nozzle on a daily basis.

1.1 Checking with Software

How to check for nozzle dirt with the [Tip Cln Check] button

The term “nozzle dirt” here refers to a condition in which solder or other material has adhered to the

nozzle tip and is shining. This shiny portion might be mistaken for a component and cause recognition

errors. “Tip Cleanliness Check” is a function that determines the degree of nozzle dirt by recognizing

the nozzle tip with no components using the camera.

NOTE

The [Tip Cln Check] is a function that recognizes the reflection of the light around the nozzle center. Therefore, applicable nozzles are those with a small tip, such as Type 8104A and 8105A.

Step 1 (When the nozzle station is not equipped) Replace the nozzle.

1. Press the [Required nozzles] button on the

“Setup” screen to check the nozzles to be

used for production.

2. Press the emergency stop button and

detach the feeder exchange carriage. Then

open the machine safety cover.

3. Attach nozzles to be used for production to

head.

open the machine safety cover.

3. Attach nozzles to be used for production to

head.

4. Close the machine safety cover and attach

the feeder exchange carriage. Then cancel

the emergency stop.

NOTE

Step 1 can be skipped if the machine is equipped with the nozzle station.

Step 2 Press the [Tip Cln Check] button.

Press the [Tip Cln Check] button on the “Setup”

screen.

How to check for clogged nozzles on the [unit] > [head] tab screen

The term “clogged nozzle” here refers to a condition in which material such as solder or other material

has adhered into the nozzle hole and the negative pressure increases even if no component is being

picked up with the nozzle. In this condition, there is a possibility of no-component mounting.

Check for clogged nozzles with the following procedures. The checking procedure differs between the

HM, FM, and LM heads and the RM head, so this section describes each one.

HM, FM, and LM heads and the RM head, so this section describes each one.

For HM, FM, and LM heads

Here describes the procedure of HM head with Type 8104A as example.

TIP

The “vacuum level when nozzle is open”, which is the criterion for nozzle clogging, differs depending on the nozzle type. For vacuum levels when nozzle is open, except for the Type 8104A nozzle, see the next section “1.1.1 Vacuum Level When nozzle Is Open”.

Step 1 Attach the nozzle.

When nozzle station is not equipped

1. Press the emergency stop button and

detach the feeder exchange carriage. Then

open the machine safety cover.

2. Attach Type 8104A nozzles to all head.

When nozzle station is equipped

1. Press the [nozzle Change] button on the

[unit] > [head] tab screen and attach the

Type 8104A nozzle to all head.

2. Perform “Table select” and attach the

nozzles to both A and B heads.

Step 2 Reset the numerical figure.

Open the [unit] > [head] tab screen to reset the

Step 2 Reset the numerical figure.

Open the [unit] > [head] tab screen to reset the

vacuum level value by pressing the [Reset]

button at lower right of screen. Perform table

selection and reset all the values.

Step 3 Generate negative pressure.

Press the [Vacuum] buttons of all head on the

[unit] > [head] tab screen. When the value

starts rising, wait five to ten seconds and set

to OFF. Perform table selection and execute

this task to all tables.

Step 1-3 Generating negative pressure

Example: HM head in Dual-stage type

Path Image Generating negative pressure : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Checking_Nozzle_Conditions/Chapter_2_Daily_Maintenance_Items_1_1.1_Generating_negative_pressure.png

Step 4 Check the vacuum levels.

Check all “Max” values shown in red on the vacuum pressure result, by changing-over tables. If this value is 170 to 200, then it is in normal range.

If higher than 200, then the nozzle hole might be dirty. See “1.2 nozzle Cleaning” in Chapter

3 to clean the nozzle.

Step 4 Checking negative pressure

Path Image Checking negative pressure : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Checking_Nozzle_Conditions/Chapter_2_Daily_Maintenance_Items_1_1.1_Checking_negative_pressure.png

TIP

If a correct value cannot be obtained from Steps 1 to 4 even after cleaning nozzle, the interior of the spline shaft might be dirty. See “5.1.1 Cleaning Spline Shaft Interior” for HM head and “5.2.1 Cleaning Spline Shaft Interior” for FM head in Chapter 3 for cleaning procedure of the spline shaft interior.

For RM head

Here describes the procedure of Type 8106A as example.

TIP

The “vacuum level when nozzle is open”, which is the criterion for nozzle clogging, differs depending on the nozzle type. For vacuum levels when nozzle is open, except for the Type 8104A nozzle, see the next section “1.1.1 Vacuum Level When nozzle Is Open”.

Step 1 Attach the nozzle.

When nozzle station is not equipped

1. Press the emergency stop button and

detach the feeder exchange carriage. Then

open the machine safety cover.

2. Attach Type 8106A nozzles to all head.

When nozzle station is equipped

1. Press the [nozzle Change] button and

attach the Type 8106A nozzle to all head.

2. Perform “Table select” and attach the

nozzles to both A and B heads.

Step 2 Release the emergency stop.

NOTE

The checking of negative pressure of RM head should be performed under the condition of turning the servo ON.

Step 3 Reset values.

Reset values of vacuum level by pressing the [Reset] button at lower right of the [unit] > [head] tab screen. Reset every tables by selecting tables.

NOTE

Check negative pressure of the RM head one by one.

Step 1-3 Attaching nozzle and resetting value

Example: Dual-stage type

Step 1-3 Attaching nozzle and resetting value

Example: Dual-stage type

Step 4 Generate negative pressure.

1. Select any rod (Valve-axis: Spool up-anddown axis) by pressing the “Rod Select” button. Each of rod 1 or 2 can be selected.

2. Select head by pressing the “head Select” button, then the selected head moves to beneath the selected rod by rotating the rotary of head unit.

3. Pressing the [Vacuum Check] button on the selected rod side activates the vacuum pump to generate negative pressure at the selected head. Press the [Vacuum Check] button again after raising the value in five to ten seconds to turn the vacuum pump OFF.

1. Check the “Maximum” value displayed in red at vacuum status. When the value is 160 or less means normal.

2. When the value is more than 160, the nozzle hole may not be cleaned, or the filter may be clogging. See “1.2.1 Cleaning and Lubricating Shaft Mating Part and Spring Action Part” in “1.2

 nozzle Cleaning” of Chapter 3 to clean the nozzle or replace the filter.

1.2 Checking Nozzles Visually

To visually check nozzles, remove each nozzle from the head or from the nozzle station.

Points to check detached nozzles

Check the detached nozzles using a magnifying glass or similar tool.

 nozzle condition check points

How to check nozzles by detaching them from head individually

How to check nozzles by detaching them from head individually

1. Move the head to a position where the nozzles can be easily detached, then detach each nozzle

manually.

2. after checking and cleaning the nozzle, reattach the nozzle to the head while making sure the head

position and the nozzle's direction are correct.

NOTE

As for a simple method, check the nozzle attached to the head with a mirror or similar tool.

How to check nozzles by removing the entire nozzle holder

If the nozzle station (option) is equipped, you can check nozzles by removing the entire nozzle holder

with nozzles from the nozzle station base unit.

See “How to Detach/Attach nozzle Holder” in this chapter for details.

2 Inspecting Nozzle Station

2.1 Inspecting and Cleaning Nozzle Holder, and Checking Sensor Condition

The nozzle holder should be inspected and cleaned daily for chips or debris.

A sensor is mounted on the base unit of the nozzle station to check that the nozzle holder is attached

correctly. It is also necessary to check if that sensor works properly.

 nozzle station

 nozzle holder (removable)

Path Image nozzle holder (removable) : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Inspecting_Nozzle_Station/Chapter_2_Daily_Maintenance_Items_2_2.1_Nozzle_station_holder_removable.png

Step 1 Detach the nozzle holder.

Refer to “How to detach nozzle holder” on page 2-4 of this chapter to detach the nozzle holder from

the base unit.

Step 2 Remove the nozzles.

Open the nozzle holder shutter and remove all the nozzles.

Step 3 Clean the nozzle holder.

Check for chips or debris in the nozzle holder.

If there are chips or debris, remove them using the air blow tool (optional) etc.

If the position check marks (that is, ANC MACS) and QR code are dirty, wipe them dry using a

metadata.sub_section: 2.1|Inspecting and Cleaning Nozzle Holder, and Checking Sensor Condition

content:
If the position check marks (that is, ANC MACS) and QR code are dirty, wipe them dry using a

lint-free cloth or cotton swab.

Step 4 Clean the base unit of the nozzle station.

• Check for dirt or foreign matter on the base unit.

If there is dirt or foreign matter, wipe them off using lint-free cloth etc.

• If there is dirt or dust on the sensor part, remove it using lint-free cloth or a blower brush etc.

Step 5 Return the nozzles to the nozzle holder.

Return the nozzles to their original positions in the nozzle holder.

CAUTION

When returning the nozzle, be sure to align the notch of the nozzle with the positioning pin in the nozzle pocket and insert it.

Returning nozzles to nozzle holder

Path Image Returning nozzles to nozzle holder : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Inspecting_Nozzle_Station/Chapter_2_Daily_Maintenance_Items_2_2.1_Returning_nozzles_nozzle_holder.png

Step 6 Check the movement of the nozzle holder shutter.

metadata.sub_section: 2.1|Inspecting and Cleaning Nozzle Holder, and Checking Sensor Condition

content:
Step 6 Check the movement of the nozzle holder shutter.

Open and close the nozzle holder shutter to check if the shutter moves smoothly.

Step 7 Attach the nozzle holder to the base unit.

Refer to “How to attach nozzle holder” on page 2-4 of this chapter to attach the nozzle holder to

the base unit.

Step 8 Check that the sensor has detected the nozzle holder.

1. Close the machine safety cover and release the emergency stop.

2. Check that the sensor has detected the nozzle holder on the [unit] > [I/O] tab screen.

metadata.sub_section: 2.1|Inspecting and Cleaning Nozzle Holder, and Checking Sensor Condition

3 Cleaning Feeder Plate and Related

Chips or foreign object falling on the feeder plate or the clamp unit may be bitten in between the parts

during feeder setting and cause the pick-up position to deviate. Also, the chips or foreign object which are bitten when attaching the feeder exchange carriage may cause the communication error or similar.

Periodic inspection and cleaning are recommended to prevent this problem.

Cleaning with vacuum cleaner

1. Detach the feeder exchange carriage from the machine.

2. Use a household vacuum cleaner, etc. to suction the dust and small debris.

Cleaning with vacuum assembly

1. Connect the optional vacuum assembly (KHY-M88V0-A0) to the air connectors on the front of the

feeder exchange carriage.

2. Suction the dust and small debris using a vacuum assembly.

Vacuum assembly connection

Connecting to air connector on feeder exchange carriage

1. Detach the feeder exchange carriage from the machine.

2. Using a feeder plate cleaning brush, sweep out the chips and debris in the direction of arrow shown

in the figure below.

4 Checking Tape Cutter Sharpness

The used carrier tape after mounting components are automatically cut by tape cutters in the machine and collected in empty tape box. If a tape cutter loses the sharpness, carrier tapes that are not cut may clog in the path to the empty tape box. Check tape cutter sharpness everyday.

tape cutter and empty tape box

Path Image tape cutter and empty tape box : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Checking_Tape_Cutter_Sharpness/Chapter_2_Daily_Maintenance_Items_4_Tape_cutter_and_empty_box.png

Three checkpoints of daily tape cutter inspection

• The sound when cutting tape is normal.

Check that the sound of tape cutter moving is not louder than usual.

Check that abnormal sound such as metal sound is not heard.

• Carrier tapes in the empty tape box are cut appropriately.

Check the cut sections of carrier tapes when disposing of carrier tapes in the empty tape box.

• Carrier tapes in the empty tape box are disposed of.

• Carrier tapes in the empty tape box are disposed of.

Check the empty tape box everyday and dispose of accumulated carrier tapes.

CAUTION

As used carrier tapes accumulates in the empty tape box, dispose of them periodically. If the empty tape box is filled with them, trouble such as cutter operation error may occur.

NOTE

Lubricating tape cutter with disassembly, and replacing tape cutter blade must be performed by a service representative as failure in these tasks cause serious injury. Contact your distributor when tape cutter abnormality is noticed.

1 Weekly Maintenance

Here describes the maintenance items required to perform once a week.

1.1 Nozzle Inspection

The troubles of the spring action or the nozzle leaf spring lead the pick-up error.

Inspect each nozzle to prevent the troubles.

1.1.1 Inspection of Spring Action Part

Check the nozzle spring action condition. When a nozzle is pushed and it returns to its original position

normally, there is no problem. If it does not, pick-up error or recognition error may occur.

CAUTION

• Touching the nozzle tip directly by finger may cause adherence of oil or so. Use such as a flat plate* instead.

• When pushing a nozzle tip to check its condition, do not push too much. It is enough when a nozzle returns after it is pushed approximately 1 mm.

Condition of nozzle spring action

Type 8104A nozzle as example

Path Image Condition of nozzle spring action : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Weekly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_1_1.1_1.1.1_Condition_nozzle_spring.png

NOTE

* As a “flat plate”, use the nozzle spring action check sheet (KLG-M9706-00) recommended by YAMAHA or something that meets the following conditions.

• Use something hard enough to check the nozzle spring action.

• Use something hard enough to check the nozzle spring action.

• Use something that will not get scratched even if the nozzle tip is pressed against it.

TIP

See “1.1 Replacing Spring and O-Ring” in Chapter 5 for details of the spring replacement.

1.1.2 Condition Check of Nozzle Leaf Spring and Roller Lock Unit

Check the nozzle holding condition of heads periodically.

If the nozzle leaf spring (hereinafter referred to as leaf spring) is deformed or the roller lock unit has slack, the nozzle holding ability deteriorates, which has negative effects on the component pick-up, recognition, and mounting.

metadata.sub_sub_section: 1.1.2|Condition Check of Nozzle Leaf Spring and Roller Lock Unit

content:
1.1.2.1 HM Head

1. Check that the heads have enough nozzle holding ability by detaching the nozzle from the head tip manually.

2. Check that the fixing screws of the leaf springs are not loose.

3. Check that there is no clearance between the leaf spring and nozzle.

4. Check that there is no deformation or wear on the leaf springs.

Condition check for leaf spring

For HM head

Path Image Condition check for leaf spring : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Weekly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_1_1.1_1.1.2_1.1.2.1_Condition_leaf_spring.png

metadata.sub_sub_section: 1.1.2|Condition Check of Nozzle Leaf Spring and Roller Lock Unit

content:
1.1.2.2 FM Head

1. Check that the heads have enough nozzle holding ability by detaching the nozzle from the head tip manually.

2. Check that the fixing bolts of the leaf springs are not loose.

3. Check that there is no clearance between the leaf spring and nozzle arm assembly.

4. Check that there is no deformation or wear on the leaf springs.

5. Check that the rollers are not scratched.

Condition check for leaf spring and roller lock unit

For FM head

Path Image Condition check for leaf spring and roller lock unit : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Weekly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_1_1.1_1.1.2_1.1.2.2_Condition_leaf_spring_roller_lock.png

metadata.sub_sub_section: 1.1.2|Condition Check of Nozzle Leaf Spring and Roller Lock Unit

content:
1.1.2.3 LM Head

1. Check that the heads have enough nozzle holding ability by detaching the adapter nozzle from the head tip manually.

2. Check that the fixing bolts of the leaf springs are not loose.

3. Check that there is no clearance between the leaf spring and roller lock unit.

4. Check that there is no deformation or wear on the leaf springs.

5. Check that the rollers are not scratched.

Condition check for leaf spring and roller lock unit

For LM head

Path Image Condition check for leaf spring and roller lock unit : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Weekly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_1_1.1_1.1.2_1.1.2.3_Condition_leaf_spring_roller_lock_LM.png

TIP

metadata.sub_sub_section: 1.1.2|Condition Check of Nozzle Leaf Spring and Roller Lock Unit

content:
TIP

If there is a problem with the head parts shown above, see “2.1 Replacing nozzle Leaf Springs” or “2.2 Replacing Roller Lock unit (nozzle Arm Assembly)” in Chapter 5 for HM and FM heads, “2.1.3 LM head” in Chapter 5 to replace the nozzle leaf springs for LM head, and “2.2.2 LM head” in Chapter 5 to replace the roller lock unit for LM head. If only one of the leaf springs or rollers has deteriorated, be sure to replace it with a pair.

NOTE

If the nozzles are removed from the head or nozzle station, be sure to return them to their original position.

1.2.1 Cleaning and Lubricating Shaft Mating Part and Spring Action Part

The following describes how to clean and lubricate the nozzle shaft mating part and nozzle spring action

part. If lines are engraved on the sides of the nozzle shaft mating part, its nozzle does not require

lubrication of the nozzle spring action part. Additionally, for nozzles of “Type 8004H” to “Type 8108A”,

lubrication is not required if its parts number ends with “-A2” or later. Hereafter, a nozzle that does not

require lubrication will be referred to as “oil-less nozzle”.

content:
1.2.1.1 Nozzles Requiring Lubrication

Step 1 Detach nozzles.

When nozzle station is not equipped

1. Press the emergency stop button and detach the feeder exchange carriage. Then open the machine safety cover.

2. Detach the nozzles from the head.

When nozzle station is equipped

1. Store the nozzles into the nozzle holder and detach the nozzle holder.

2. Open the nozzle station shutter and detach the nozzles.

NOTE

For a machine equipped with a nozzle station, store all nozzles attached on the heads into the nozzle station by pressing the [nozzle Change] button on the [unit] > [head] tab screen, and then detach the nozzles from it.

Step 2 Clean the nozzle shaft mating part.

Clean the nozzle shaft mating part with cotton swab moistened with absolute ethanol

Step 2 Cleaning the nozzle shaft mating part

Path Image .Cleaning the nozzle shaft mating part : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Weekly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_1_1.1_1.2.1_1.2.1.1_Cleaning_nozzle_shaft.png

metadata.sub_sub_section: 1.2.1|Cleaning and Lubricating Shaft Mating Part and Spring Action Part

content:
Step 3 Clean the spring action part.

1. Apply absolute ethanol to the spring action part.

2. Clean the spring action part lightly using a toothbrush with soft and clean bristles. Then, apply absolute ethanol to the spring action part again.

3. On a lint-free cloth, remove absolute

ethanol from the nozzle using air blow tool.

Step 3 Cleaning the spring action part

Path Image Step 1 Applying absolute ethanol : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Weekly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_1_1.1_1.2.1_1.2.1.1_Cleaning_spring_step1.png

content:
Step 4 Lubricate the spring action part.

Using a precision screwdriver or similar tool with a pointed tip, apply a small amount of turbine oil just enough to soak into the spring action part.

Step 4 Lubricating spring action part

Path Image Lubricating spring action part : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Weekly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_1_1.1_1.2.1_1.2.1.1_Lubricating_spring.png

Step 5 Check the nozzle spring action.

1. Press the nozzle tip against a plate or similar* two or three times to spread turbine oil.

2. Wipe away excess oil from around the nozzle using a lint-free cloth.

NOTE

* Use the nozzle spring action check sheet (KLG-M9706-00) recommended by YAMAHA or something that meets the following conditions.

• Use something hard enough to check the nozzle

spring action.

• Use something that will not get scratched even if the

nozzle tip is pressed against it.

Step 5 Checking spring action part

nozzle tip is pressed against it.

Step 5 Checking spring action part

Path Image Checking spring action part : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Weekly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_1_1.1_1.2.1_1.2.1.1_Checking_spring_part.png

Step 6 Remove excess oil.

1. Put the nozzle tip on oil-blotting paper (or lint-free cloth if no oil-blotting paper is available)

and blow air over the nozzle tip for about five seconds using the air blow tool (option).

2. Blow air inside the nozzle from the nozzle attachment part for about five seconds.

3. Repeat the process of 1 and 2 three or four times to remove excess turbine oil from

inside the nozzle and nozzle tip.

NOTE

A thin coat of oil is enough to lubricate the spring action part.

Step 7 Check that the oil is removed.

Use a oil-blotting paper or lint-free cloth to check the residual oil inside nozzle.

Step 6, 7 Checking for residual oil

Step 8 Return nozzles to original positions.

1. Check again that no oil remains in the nozzle.

2. Return the nozzles to their original positions on the head. If the nozzles have been detached from the nozzle holder, return them to their original positions in the nozzle holder.

NOTE

For a machine equipped with a nozzle station, if a nozzle has been detached from the head by hand, return it to the nozzle holder of the nozzle station, not to the head.

1.2.1.2 Nozzles Not Requiring Lubrication (Oil-Less Nozzles)

The “oil-less nozzle” does not require lubrication for its spring action part.

Therefore, only clean its shaft mating part and spring action part.

NOTE

Even if the oil-less nozzle is lubricated with turbine oil and used as before, the nozzle quality will not be affected.

Step 1 Detach nozzles.

When nozzle station is not equipped

1. Press the emergency stop button and

detach the feeder exchange carriage.

Then open the machine safety cover.

2. Detach the nozzles from the heads.

When nozzle station is equipped

1. Store the nozzles into the nozzle holder and

detach the nozzle holder.

2. Open the nozzle station shutter and remove

the nozzles.

NOTE

For a machine equipped with a nozzle station, store all nozzles attached on the heads into the nozzle station by pressing the [nozzle Change] button on the [unit] > [head]

tab screen, and then detach the nozzles from it.

Step 2 Clean the nozzle shaft mating part.

metadata.sub_sub_section: 1.2.1|Cleaning and Lubricating Shaft Mating Part and Spring Action Part

content:
tab screen, and then detach the nozzles from it.

Step 2 Clean the nozzle shaft mating part.

Clean the nozzle shaft mating part with a cotton swab moistened with absolute ethanol.

Step 2 Cleaning the nozzle shaft mating part

Path Image Cleaning the nozzle shaft mating part : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Weekly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_1_1.1_1.2.1_1.2.1.2_Cleaning_nozzle_shaft_mating.png

Step 3 Clean the nozzle spring action part.

1. Apply absolute ethanol to the spring action part.

2. Clean the spring action part lightly using a toothbrush with soft and clean bristles. Then, apply absolute ethanol to the spring action part again.

3. On a lint-free cloth, remove absolute ethanol from the nozzle using the air blow tool.

Step 3 Cleaning the spring action part

1.2.3 Cleaning Nozzle Tip

A little dirt at the nozzle tip can be cleaned with the “nozzle tip cleaning tape” that comes with the

machine. If cleaning the nozzle with an ultrasonic cleaner (option) and then cleaning with the nozzle tip

cleaning tape, the nozzle tip can be cleaned effectively.

The following describes the cleaning procedure for the spring-action nozzle tip with an ultrasonic cleaner

and the nozzle tip cleaning tape.

CAUTION

When cleaning the nozzle tip, use YAMAHA recommended cleaning tape (TAPE,CLEANER: KGT-M8895-00) only. If using other tape, the adhesive surface may adhere to the nozzle and may cause the mounting failure.

NOTE

See the Service Information that comes with the tape for how to use the cleaning tape.

Step 1 Remove nozzles.

1. Press the emergency stop button and detach the feeder exchange carriage. Then

open the machine safety cover.

2. Remove nozzles from the head.

When nozzle station is equipped

1. Store the nozzles and detach the whole nozzle holder.

When nozzle station is equipped

1. Store the nozzles and detach the whole nozzle holder.

2. Open the nozzle station shutter and detach nozzles.

NOTE

For a machine equipped with a nozzle station, when detaching the nozzles, make sure to detach them automatically by pressing the [nozzle Change] button on the [unit] > [head] tab screen.

Step 2 Clean the spring action part.

If dust is in the spring action part, remove it with an air blow tool (option), etc.

Step 3 Clean nozzles with an ultrasonic cleaner.

1. Put nozzles into a container (such as beaker) in an ultrasonic cleaner.

2. Pour ethanol in a container until nozzles are dipped.

3. Pour water in an ultrasonic cleaner.

4. Clean nozzles with an ultrasonic cleaner for about ten minutes.

CAUTION

DO NOT pour ethanol directly into the ultrasonic cleaner. It must be poured in a beaker or similar container.

NOTE

NOTE

When cleaning a nozzle with an O-ring such as Type 8110R or Type 8011H nozzle using an ultrasonic cleaner, remove an O-ring and clean a nozzle itself only.

1.2.3.1 How to Clean Nozzles Using Nozzle Cleaning Wire

Only if the nozzle tip does not become clean even after using an ultrasonic cleaner or nozzle tip cleaning tape, use the “nozzle cleaning wire (option)” to clean it.

When using the nozzle cleaning wire, use the “wire fastening tool (option)” in combination. If you do not

use this tool, there is a possibility that the nozzle tip will become chipped.

Step 1 Cut the nozzle cleaning wire to the appropriate length.

Cut the nozzle cleaning wire to about 140 mm.

Step 2 Fasten the nozzle cleaning wire onto the right-hand nut side of the wire fastening tool.

1. Place the wire fastening tool with the engraved “TAKIGEN” mark side facing you,

and loosen the right-hand nut.

2. The wire fastening tool has a hole in the position shown in the right figure, so thread

the nozzle cleaning wire through this hole. At this time, thread the wire between the

two washers.

3. Sandwich the nozzle cleaning wire between the two washers to fasten it in place.

1.2.4 Checking and Cleaning Adapter Nozzle for LM Head

On the LM heads, the standard nozzles cannot be attached directly to the nozzle arm assemblies, so they are attached using the adapter nozzles. The following describes how to check the condition of the adapter nozzle and how to clean it.

metadata.sub_sub_section: 1.2.4|Checking and Cleaning Adapter Nozzle for LM Head

content:
1.2.4.1 Condition Check for Adapter Nozzle

Check the nozzle holding condition of adapter nozzles periodically.

If the nozzle leaf spring (hereinafter referred to as leaf spring) is deformed or the roller lock unit has slack, the nozzle holding ability deteriorates, which has negative effects on the component pick-up, recognition, and mounting.

Check points for leaf spring and roller lock unit

1. Check that the adapter nozzles have enough nozzle holding ability by detaching the nozzle from the adapter nozzle manually.

2. Check that the fixing bolts of the leaf springs are not loose.

3. Check that there is no deformation or wear on the leaf springs.

4. Check that the rollers are not scratched.

Check points of the leaf spring and rolloer lock unit

For adapter nozzle

Path Image Check points of the leaf spring and rolloer lock unit : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Weekly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_1_1.1_1.2.4_1.2.4.1_Check_leaf_spring_adapter_nozzle.png

CAUTION

metadata.sub_sub_section: 1.2.4|Checking and Cleaning Adapter Nozzle for LM Head

content:
CAUTION

If the leaf springs need to be replaced after checking its condition,do not reuse their fixing bolts. Be sure to use new leaf spring fixing bolts for replacement.

TIP

If there is a problem with the adapter nozzle shown above, see “2.2.3 Adapter nozzle” in Chapter 5 to replace the leaf springs or rollers. If only one of the leaf springs or rollers has deteriorated, be sure to replace it with a pair.

metadata.sub_sub_section: 1.2.4|Checking and Cleaning Adapter Nozzle for LM Head

1.2.4.2 Cleaning Adapter Nozzle

To maintain the adapter nozzles, clean the nozzle attachment holes and the air path.

The following describes how to clean the adapter nozzle.

NOTE

Be sure to remove the nozzles from the adapter nozzles before cleaning the nozzle attachment holes and the air path.

Cleaning the top surface and nozzle attachment holes

• Clean the top surface of the adapter nozzle using a lint-free cloth.

• Clean the nozzle attachment holes in the center and at the edge of the top surface of the adapter

nozzle using the air blow tool.

Cleaning the adapter nozzle

Cleaning the air path

• Clean the two air path holes located on both sides of the nozzle attachment hole in the center of the

adapter nozzle top surface using a nozzle cleaning wire.

1.3 Recognition Unit

1.3.1 Cleaning Multi-Vision Camera Lighting's Protective Glass

Adhered dust, etc., on the multi-vision camera lighting's protective glass can cause component recognition errors. To prevent this, inspect and clean it in a periodic manner.

Step 1 Blow dust off the lighting's protective glass.

1. Press the emergency stop button and

detach the feeder exchange carriage. Then

open the machine safety cover.

2. Blow dust off the lighting's protective glass

using a blower brush.

TIP

A lens blower brush is available as an optional item.

Step 1 Blowing off dust with the blower brush

Step 2 Wipe the lighting's protective glass

with a cloth or cleaning paper. Wipe the lighting's protective glass with

lint-free cloth or cleaning paper with a small amount of lens cleaner.

NOTE

A lens cleaner and cleaning paper are optional items.

TIP

NOTE

A lens cleaner and cleaning paper are optional items.

TIP

If dust or debris still remains even after cleaning as described above, clean the backside of the protective glass and the light-emitting surface referring to

“4.1.2 Multi-Vision camera” in this chapter.

1.4 RM Head Unit

1.4.1 How to Lower RM Head Nozzle Shafts

Maintenance of the RM head requires lowering the nozzle shafts manually in sequence as for example in “1.4.2 Checking for Filter Clogging” and “3.2.1 Checking Spline Shaft Z-axis Operation” in this chapter. Here describes the lowering procedure of RM head nozzle shaft.

Step 1 Press down the Z-axis of the RM head.

The Z-axis units are installed on both sides of the RM head unit to lower the nozzle shaft. By pressing down the Z-axis with a finger, the nozzle shaft can be lowered to the underside of the Z-axis.

Step 2 Change the nozzle shaft to be lowered.

Move any nozzle shaft to beneath Z-axis by turning the N-axis gear to rotate the rotary.

CAUTION

Make sure that all nozzle shafts have returned to upper end after having lowered the nozzle shafts manually.

Lowering RM head nozzle shaft

	Path Image Lowering RM head nozzle shaft : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Weekly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_1_1.4_1.4.1_Lowering_RM_head_nozzle.png

1.4.2 Checking for Filter Clogging

The filters should be checked for clogging generally once a week, depending on the supply air condition

and operating time. The filter clogging check is performed on the [unit] > [head] tab screen in a state of no nozzle.

Step 1 Detach nozzles.

1. Press the emergency stop button and

detach the feeder exchange carriage.

Then open the machine safety cover.

2. Detach nozzles from the head.

When nozzle station is equipped

1. Press the [nozzle Change] button on the

[unit] > [head] tab screen. Select “ALL” for

“head Number” and “Store nozzle” for

“nozzle type”.

2. Press the [OK] button to store the nozzles

of all heads in the nozzle holder.

3. Select the table in “Table Select” and store

the nozzles of both RM head units A and B.

NOTE

For a machine equipped with a nozzle station, when detaching the nozzles, make sure to detach them automatically by pressing the [nozzle Change] button on the [unit] > [head] tab screen.

Step 2 Cancel the emergency stop.

NOTE

Step 2 Cancel the emergency stop.

performed with the servo on.

level value. Select the table in “Table Select” and reset the values for all table.

NOTE

Negative pressure of RM head should be checked one head at a time.

1.4.3 Replacing Air Filters

The filters for the RM head cannot be reused. If the filter is dirty, or if the standard value without nozzle is

greater than 130 in “1.4.2 Checking for Filter Clogging” above, replace the filters.

It is recommended to replace the filters with new ones once a month.

2 Monthly Maintenance

This section describes mainly the procedures for cleaning and lubricating after inspecting the X-axis ball

screw and guide, and Y-axis guides and linear scales. The inspection points and cautions are given below.

Inspection points

1. Any foreign matter adhering to the ball screws or guides?

Check if any fallen chips have adhered onto the ball screws or guides.

2. Do the ball screws and guides have the correct amount of grease?

Check if grease has flowed off or splattered in the air failing to adhere.

Also check if grease has discolored or hardened.

3. Any abnormal sounds from the ball screws?

Press the emergency stop button.

Then check for any abnormal sounds while pushing the X-axis manually.

Countermeasures

1. ball screws and linear guides may be damaged when chips and other material bite into them.

If chips are adhering, wipe them off along with the grease or remove with tweezers, etc.

2. Apply grease referring to “Cleaning and lubrication” described later on.

2. Apply grease referring to “Cleaning and lubrication” described later on.

3. Contact your distributor when abnormal sounds occur even after trying the countermeasures in the

above steps 1 and 2.

Precautions

WARNING

THIS machine CONTAINS PARTS GENERATING STRONG MAGNETIC FIELDS. GREAT CARE SHOULD BE TAKEN WHEN A PART OF YOUR BODY IS PUT INSIDE THE machine FOR THE MAINTENANCE WORK. CAUTIONS REGARDING FERROMAGNETIC FIELDS ARE DESCRIBED IN THE SECTION, “SAFETY INSTRUCTIONS”, AT THE BEGINNING OF THIS DOCUMENT. ALWAYS THOROUGHLY READ THIS SECTION TO FULLY UNDERSTAND ITS CONTENTS.

CAUTION

If abnormal noise is emitted from the ball screw or linear guide of each axis, contact your distributor. Disassembly and cleaning of the ball screw or linear guide by the user will void the warranty.

CAUTION

When performing the cleaning and greasing work, use square cloth to prevent parts from being lost or entering the Y-axis linear part.

CAUTION

CAUTION

When handling grease, read the safety precautions stated in “Safety Instructions” and “2.3.2 Lubricating Tools and Grease” in Chapter 1.

2.1 X-Axis

This section describes the inspection, cleaning, and lubrication procedures for X-axis. For details on the

lubrication points and schedule, see “Chapter 4 Lubrication Points List”. Prepare grease guns (with

standard nozzle) and the specified grease (NSL).

and push-up plate.

grease spattering prevention cover to right

to remove.

reversing the above removal procedure.

reversing the above removal procedure.

handle.

wipe the opposite-side ball screw.

When cleaning the ball screw, carefully clean its groove area as well. after cleaning, make sure that no dust, lint or debris remains on the ball screw.

2.3 Conveyor Unit

2.3.1 Checking Conveyor Sensor and Its Operation

The conveyor sensor checks whether a board exists/ not exists, or its transit. The YRM20/YRM20DL uses through-beam fiber sensors as conveyor sensor. When a board is placed on the conveyor, the sensor judges a board exists as the beam emitted from sensor is shaded by a board.

The beam receiving condition of sensor will vary depending the distance between the beam emitter and

receiver when changing the conveyor width. When changing the conveyor rail width, the conveyor Sensor Tuning function will be actuated to rewrite the sensor threshold value automatically by remembering the changing receiving condition of sensor. It is required to be checked periodically if it operates correctly.

Checking conveyor sensor and its operation

Path Image Checking conveyor sensor and its operation : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Monthly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_2_2.3_2.3.1_Checking_conveyor_sensor.png

How to check

Step 1 Prepare for work.

How to check

Step 1 Prepare for work.

Check that there are no board on the conveyor

nor pushup pins at the conveyor motion range.

Step 2 Change the conveyor width.

1. Open the [unit] > [conveyor] tab screen and

press the [Width] button.

2. conveyor width change screen will appear,

then input any conveyor width and press

the [OK] button.

Step 2 Changing conveyor width

Path Image Changing conveyor width : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Monthly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_2_2.3_2.3.1_Changing_conveyor_width.png

Step 3 Make sure there is no error.

after changing the conveyor width, if no error

message appears, the conveyor sensor is

operating normally. No further operation is

required.

When error message appears.

Perform the conveyor sensor tuning as following procedure.

Step 1 Perform the conveyor sensor tuning.

1. Press the [Sensor Tune] button on the right

side of the [unit] > [conveyor] tab screen.

1. Press the [Sensor Tune] button on the right

side of the [unit] > [conveyor] tab screen.

2. The “Confirmation of conveyor sensor

tuning” screen will appear. Press the [OK]

button to recalculate the threshold value by

assuming that the current sensor condition

has no boards.

Step 1 Performing conveyor sensor tuning

Path Image  Performing conveyor sensor tuning : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Monthly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_2_2.3_2.3.1_Performing_conveyor_sensor.png

Step 2 Check the sensor condition.

Change the conveyor width again, then check

if any error message appears.

The conveyor sensor tuning finishes when no

error message appears.

When error message still appears.

It may be the beam receiving condition deterioration around the sensor, the sensor (amplifier) breakage,

or the fiber broken.

Remove dirt and dust on the sensor unit using a lint-free cloth or a lens blower brush, then check that
no error message appears after changing the conveyor width again.

2.4 RM Head Unit

2.4.1 Cleaning Side-View Camera and Its Lighting

The prism and lighting of the side-view camera are installed on the head unit. after the long time operation, the prism and lighting become dirty with dust etc., this may cause false recognition. It is recommended to clean them once a month.

CAUTION

Do not apply strong force to the camera unit during cleaning. As the glass parts are equipped inside of the camera, they may be damaged.

Step 1 Store all the nozzles.

1. Open the [unit] > [head] tab screen.

2. Select any head unit from “Table Select”.

3. Press the [nozzle Change] button.

4. Select “ALL” for “head Number” and select

“Store nozzle” for “nozzle Type” on the

“nozzle Change” screen.

5. Press the [OK] button to return all nozzles

into the nozzle station.

NOTE

For a machine equipped with a nozzle station, when detaching the nozzles, make sure to detach them automatically by pressing the [nozzle Change] button on the [unit] > [head] tab screen.

NOTE

NOTE

When the nozzle station is not equipped, press the emergency stop button and remove the nozzles by hand.

Step 1 Storing nozzle (for machine with nozzle station)

	Path Image Storing nozzle (for machine with nozzle station) : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Monthly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_2_2.4_2.4.1_Storing_nozzle_machine_nozzle.png

Step 2 Move the head unit.

1. Remove all items sensitive to magnetic

fields such as wristwatches and magnetic

ID cards.

2. Press the emergency stop button and

detach the feeder exchange carriage.

3. Open the machine safety cover and move

the head unit by hand to the position

convenient to work.

Step 3 Clean the prism.

Remove dust around the prism from the back

of the head unit using a blower brush.

CAUTION

Make sure to use a blower brush for cleaning the prism. Cleaning with a lint-free cloth or similar object may apply strong force to the prism, which may cause the prism to move.

Step 3 Cleaning the prisms

Path Image  Cleaning the prisms : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Maintenance_Manual/Monthly_Maintenance/Chapter_3_Periodic_Maintenance_Items_2_2.4_2.4.1_Cleaning_prisms.png

Step 4 Clean the lighting.

Clean the lighting by dry-wiping with a lint-free

cloth or a cleaning paper.

CAUTION

Do not use a solvent. Using a solvent may cause the surface coat of the lighting or prism to damage, or to discolor.

NOTE

The blower brush and the cleaning paper are available as an option.

2.5 Feeder Exchange Carriage and Clamp Unit on machine Side

2.5.1Feeder Exchange Carriage and Positioning Parts on machine Side

Basically, the cleaning and lubrication for two positioning pins of the feeder exchange carriage and two

positioning holes on the machine are required once a month. Clean and lubricate the four locations show in the figure below.

Step 1 Wipe away old grease using a lint-free cloth.

1. Using a lint-free cloth, wipe away old grease and dirt from the two positioning pins of the feeder exchange carriage.

2. Using a lint-free cloth, wipe away old grease and dirt from the two positioning holes of the

machine.

Step 2 Apply an appropriate amount of grease (NSL) using a cotton swab.

1. Using a cotton swab, apply an appropriate amount of grease (NSL) to the two positioning pins of the feeder exchange carriage.

2. Using a cotton swab, apply an appropriate amount of grease (NSL) to the two positioning holes of the machine.

2.5.2 Cleaning and Lubricating Cam Follower of Feeder Exchange Carriage

Basically, cleaning and lubrication of the cam follower of feeder exchange carriage are required once a

month.

Step 1 Detach the feeder exchange carriage.

1. Press the emergency stop button.

2. Turn off the carriage clamp switch and detach the feeder exchange carriage.

Step 2 Clean up the cam followers.

Wipe away old grease and dirt from seven cam followers of the feeder exchange carriage using a lint-free cloth.

Step 3 Apply grease to the cam followers.

With fingers wearing protective gloves, apply a thin layer of specified grease (NSL) to the cam

followers. Wipe away the excessive grease.

Cam follower

Cleaning and lubrication points
